intro: Alyxia bracteolosa var. parvifolia, commonly known as the small-leaved mistletoe, is a parasitic plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the family Violaceae and is characterized by its small, oval-shaped leaves and white, fragrant flowers. The plant typically grows on the branches of live oaks and other hardwood trees, drawing nutrients and water from its host. Its fruit is a small, fleshy capsule that contains numerous tiny seeds, which are dispersed by birds. This species plays an important ecological role in its habitat, supporting a variety of wildlife.
